sections.title: Turn Savings into Sustainable Income
sections.subtitle: Design a withdrawal plan that balances longevity risk, taxes, and market volatility

sections.title: What You'll Do
items: Understand sequencing risk and withdrawal rules
Compare fixed, variable, and guardrail withdrawal methods
Create a personal withdrawal policy statement

sections.title: Decumulation Challenges
sections.content: Retirement income planning flips accumulation on its head. Sequence-of-returns risk means early market losses can drain portfolios faster if withdrawals stay constant. Blending flexible withdrawal policies with cash buffers helps smooth income during downturns.

points.title: 4% Rule
points.description: Inflation-adjusted withdrawals starting at 4% of the portfolio historically lasted 30 years for balanced portfolios, but requires flexibility during weak markets.

points.title: Guardrail Method
points.description: Withdraw a starting percentage but adjust up or down if portfolio growth crosses preset guardrails (e.g., +/- 20%).

points.title: Bucket Strategy
points.description: Segment assets into cash (0-3 years), bonds (3-10 years), and stocks (10+ years) so you can ride out equity volatility.

sections.title: Tax-Smart Order
sections.content: A common sequence: taxable accounts first, then tax-deferred (traditional IRA/401(k)), saving Roth accounts for last. Adjust based on tax brackets and required minimum distributions (RMDs).

sections.title: Account Coordination
sections.content: Track required minimum distributions starting at age 73. Blend withdrawals with Social Security, pensions, and annuities. Execute Roth conversions in low-income years to reduce future RMDs and Medicare surcharges.

sections.title: Withdrawal Strategy Workshop
steps: List guaranteed income sources for each year of retirement.
Select a withdrawal method (4% rule, guardrail, or bucket) and document why it fits your risk tolerance.
Create a 12-month cash flow calendar showing which accounts fund each month's expenses.
Draft rules for adjusting withdrawals after market gains or losses (e.g., cut 10% if portfolio falls 15%).
Schedule annual reviews to reassess tax brackets, RMDs, and spending needs.

sections.title: Use Dynamic Guardrails
sections.content: Set a floor and ceiling for withdrawals (e.g., 3% minimum, 5% maximum). Staying within the range keeps income stable while protecting portfolio longevity.
